This isn't quite true, as the launchpad builders are still configured to push to latest/edge so there's already drift here. I'd propose instead something along the lines of:

Available charm updates are determined by which track and risk level they follow. The ``latest/stable`` track contains the OpenStack charms versions published with the 21.10 stable release (and the 21.06 stable release of the Trilio Charms). Deploying from the ``latest`` track will eventually lead to problems in the future and users are advised to avoid installing from the latest track. It is expected this track will be closed and will no longer be available after a several month grace period to allow for users to migrate to the appropriate tracks. All future maintenance will be on the various tracks and users will need to migrate.

I've been mulling this piece over, and while I am a strong proponent of closing the track this decision has not been finalized. Instead, can we say that doing so may cause a future charm upgrade to receive a charm version that no longer supports your current OpenStack release?

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message:
not sure why this is needed.  Are we writing to this directory currently?   Bind mounts should still work even with a readonly /usr.

I think it would be odd to have executables living in /etc intentionally.

Also, doing this will break the existing setup, where /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/kubeadm.conf is a symlink to /usr/local/kubernetes/current/stage2/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/kubeadm.conf
In new setup, the symlink is pointing to /etc/kubernetes/local/current/stage2/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/kubeadm.conf

To work with a readonly /usr I think we'd have to create the "current/stageX" directories as part of the filesystem at loadbuild.

The directories for the various versions should be created as part of the various versioned kubernetes packages.

it is not the directories being created, it is the {{ kube_local_dir }}/current/stage1 and {{ kube_local_dir }}/current/stage2 being written to, depends on which version of kube is "current". 
Are you suggesting to make /usr/local/kubernetes a new mount?

The comment for the highlighted code literally says "Create Kubernetes bind mounts directories" and the code in question is ensuring that four directories exist and have the right owner and permissions.

I'm not sure this code is necessary though, since /usr/local/kubernetes/current/stage1 and /usr/local/kubernetes/current/stage2 are created by the "kubernetes_unversioned" package, and /usr/local/kubernetes/<version>/stage1 and /usr/local/kubernetes/<version>/stage2 will be created by the "kubernetes-<version>-kubeadm" package. 


In the current setup, at runtime {{ kube_local_dir }}/current/stage1 and {{ kube_local_dir }}/current/stage2 are bind mounts which refer to the specific version of K8s that is active.

So for example /usr/bin/kubelet is a symlink to /usr/local/kubernetes/current/stage2/usr/bin/kubelet where  /usr/local/kubernetes/current/stage2 is a bind mount of /usr/local/kubernetes/1.21.8/stage2
As I said previously, the recommendation from the Architect team is to use /opt/cni/bin which is the default place where Kubernetes will look for them.

resolutions/20220414-drop-lower-constrai.message:
I find this a bit confusing.  I suggest something along these lines:

Before pip's coherent dependency resolver, we were testing with versions of dependencies that were different from what we thought they were [5]_.  Adapting an individual project's lower-constraints.txt files to pass the coherent resolver was a lot of work, and revealed that there were problems maintaining transitive dependencies in the lower-constraints.txt (we were not systematically tracking when dependencies added new dependencies).  Further, even if we could test lower-constraints correctly in a particular project, we would still have the completeness problem mentioned in the previous point.
maybe it's also worth to mention that some projects, like e.g. Neutron already dropped it from the stable branches and is now testing it only in master branch.
maybe: the versions of their packages

"do" ?

"We can only manage the OpenStack direct dependencies lower bound since indirect dependencies, e.g. from packages outside of OpenStack, do not maintain compatible lower bounds."
yeah, we already covered it in previous point so we do not need to repeat it.

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/handlers/kur.message: We shouldn't need to worry about the subnet, it'll go away along with the network if it's unused. The only problem is making sure ports are correctly removed from it even if untagged and currently I see `delete_network_pools` relies on pools to list ports, meaning that it probably excludes untagged ports.
Do I see correctly that this only deletes ports and not the network itself? The subnet is deleted automatically with the network, but we still got to delete the network itself when ports are gone.
Is it possible for Networks with old names as well?

Not really. There is only an assumption, that if given ns name matches with network name would assure us, that this is the right resource. It might happen however, that even we got the match by name, namespace was deleted and created again with the same name. uid here is a guarantee, that we don't remove something, which we shouldn't. That's why, it is only those networks taken into account, which have identifier origin from namespace.
how there would be untagged Ports if no Pods could be created as the network information was not available in the crd?
I'm still not sure how any Port could have been created if the Network ID was not defined in the CRD. Did we see this in the perf testing?

Partially, yes. During high load it may happen:
- port has been created, but neutron API has died in the meantime, meaning we don't update corresponding kuryrportcrd nor tag the port (that happens in driver.request_vifs method)
- port has been successfully created, API return 201, but we failed to tag it due to subsequent neutron failure, resulting with port in a state like above
- port has been successfully created, but we got error during crd update, hence we could have tagged port either in up or down state depending on the binding result.
Well, tagging might failed, while port was successfully created. We need to be prepared for such situations :)

nova/virt/vmwareapi/session.py.message:
You don't need six:

  class StableMoRefProxy(metaclass=abc.ABCMeta):
I don't know the actual error modes of the morefs in vmware but this cause a RecursionError if the original problem of the moref is persistent. Should we stop retrying after N attempts?
Thanks for the explanation. I agree that we don't need to prepare for this.

The recursion depth is limited by the number of moref id changes during the execution of the function. I want to highlight that it only recurses, if a new moref id has been found.

We have a limited low number of moref as arguments,
and the moref is essentially a row-id in the underlying database.

The row-number for an object only changes when an object gets unregistered and re-registered, or the database gets restored.

So, to get into a recursion error, you'll have to do that in the time-frame the function retries, and achieve that feat 1000 times in a row.

I would put that situation the rather purely theoretical realm, and I rather would like to avoid to change the interface of the function, as it is proxying arbitrary API calls. (Probably prefixing the limit with underscore would be enough)

nova/virt/vmwareapi/vm_util.py.message: Can we change this to MoRef and passing search_vm_ref_by_identifier as the closure to re-fetch the vmMo?

The function re-fetching the reference needs to behave like get_vm_ref,
and search_vm_ref_by_identifier is explicitly implemented differently for a different use-case.

The re-fetching function needs to update the cache, and raise an InstanceNotFound exception on failure.

We only can do that, if search_vm_ref_by_identifier can made to behave the same. That's likely possible, but also a larger scope.
Thanks for the explanation. I see the reason why you separated these two cases. It is good as is.

OK so like we discussed in my huge email, what this will tell you is if any flushes have proceeded on the current transaction as well as if it has any database connections.  but looking at the code right now I would note that the transaction-level _dirty/_new/_deleted collections are actually weak referencing, because they are only used for rollbacks, so they're not by themselves reliable for this purpose.


If there's a transaction in progress, and flushes have proceeded and the transaction wasn't committed, then "transaction._connections"  should be non-empty.  that is, you can't have tranasction._dirty /_new/_deleted be non-empty with _connections being empty (I'm pretty sure of this unless I'm forgetting something).  so you *should* be able to pass all tests if you make that check "if not session.transaction._connections". 
 

at the same time, if this session has things pending for flush that haven't been flushed at all, this check wont tell you that, you would need to look in session.dirty/new/deleted.  this is probably not that important here since we would assume some operation working on other things would have flushed.

 But also we should give you APIs for this.   I would propose:


session.has_pending_flush_changes - if flush() is expected to emit SQL
session.transaction.is_live (or maybe session.transaction_is_live, or both) - if the SessionTransaction has actual DBAPI connections in progress with transactions on them, or if the transaction is just empty


less useful, since I think "is_live" is sufficient, might be 
session.transaction.has_pending_commit_state (or maybe session.has_pending_commit_state, or both), which is a flag we can switch if flushes that have proceeded in this transaction actually emitted SQL to the database.


anyway, see if "if not session.transaction._connections" works here.  are there tests which exercise this behavior?

Hello Mike, you are right on not checking the .transaction dirty/deleted/new but session ones, same as I'm doing in Neutron patch [1]

"session.transaction.is_live" is always True if the session has been used before, regardless of any pending action to be flushed. I can't used it.

The API method "has_pending_flush_changes", checking the same as I do in [1] could be perfect for us. If we have this method in 2.0 (or in a newer 1.4.x version), I'll replace n-lib/neutron code to use it.

Again, thanks a lot. With your blessing, I'll reach Neutron folks to approve those patches ASAP.

%install
mkdir -p %{buildroot}%{_sysconfdir}/cron.d

install -d %{buildroot}%{_datadir}/starlingx

%post
if [ $1 -eq 1 ] ; then
    cp -f %{_datadir}/starlingx/logrotate.conf %{_sysconfdir}/logrotate.conf
    chmod 644 %{_sysconfdir}/logrotate.conf
    mv %{_sysconfdir}/cron.daily/logrotate %{_sysconfdir}/logrotate.cron
    chmod 700 %{_sysconfdir}/logrotate.cron
fi


We want logrotate-cron.d to be installed at /etc/cron.d/logrotate.

After package is installed:
We want /usr/share/starlingx/logrotate.conf to be copied to /etc/logrotate.conf
We want /etc/cron.daily to be moved to /etc/logrotate.cron

for poor souls who stumble upon this comment in the future, which is a reasonable question/assumption, to paraphrase the bug report:

crontab won't load LANG from the passed in ENV (via docker). LANG must be specified explicitly in your crontab, in order to be available for commands run via crontab.

It might be worth investigating if this is only an issue with the curator or also affects other software started via crontab inside kolla-ansible containers.

It might be also worth to add explicit integrationtests which check that a given cronjob really was successfully executed.

as also said in the bugreport: crontab and containers are not a good match for each other in general, because crons assume a more or less standard unix system, e.g. the default mechanism to report errors in cron is via mail, but no mta or local mail delievery is configured in a standard docker container image, so you have to script some stuff to adapt oldschool crons to the modern container world.

as can be seen in this example, there is not even a check or an error thrown, if the command run by crontab doesn't work.

a more suitable option than crontabs in general might be systemd-timers, as they are afaik more designed to also be run inside containers, but this would need a time consuming rearchitecture of kolla containers which might not be currently feasible.

cinder/volume/drivers/lightos.py.message:
If I understand correctly, the way compression works for lightos is:

- The backend can do compression
- There's no special license required or anything like that, that the driver needs to communicate back to cinder for compression to be available
- The config opt 'lightos_default_compression_enabled' gives the default for whether compression will be used when there's no extra_spec in the volume type
- If there's a compression extra_spec in the volume type, it overrides the config option (so that even if lightos_default_compression_enabled=False, if the extra_spec says to use compression, compression is used)

I think under these circumstances, you want to return True here to indicate that compression is available.  (If the opt is False, that's ok, because you allow the volume-type to override.  So if someone is using a generic volume type that enables compression, the scheduler will know that it can be built on lightos.

I looked into this a bit with Gorka and he said the correct thing to do here is the list that you have, so I withdraw my objection.

You need to document somewhere (one place could be the help text for the lightos_default_compression_enabled option, but also in your driver docs) that operators should always set compression in the volume type extra_specs so that they know what they're getting.

from the sched point of view "xynz true" -> True
either that or you could do something like _parse_boolean_extra_spec() from cinder/volume/drivers/qnap.py  ... from a quick look at the drivers , seems like everyone does their own thing on this
I will add it in a follow up.

* Added call to "upgrade-charm" hook that forces cache to be updated with all previously issued certificates. This fixes the problem when vault charm is upgraded from older version that did not have a cache to a new version with cache.
* Added precautions when loading global client cert from leader storage

My testing bundle was cdk+vault (so kubernetes-master and kubernetes-worker were cert recipients.) and worked as expected.

I managed to reproduce your issues Rodrigo. Non-leader vault units sync certificates data from cache to relations when cache gets updated and that happens only when new certificates are issued (or old ones removed). In your setup the certificates were issued by the old vault units that had no cache. Then after the charm upgrade, there was a cache, but no new certificates were issued so nothing got stored in it.
This is definitely an issue. I'll work on including copying certificates to cache on charm upgrade.

In the meantime, this can be "fixed" by removing and re-adding the relation with vault. (Or running the 'reissue-certificates' vault action)

Hi Folks,

I have some interesting news from Luigi regarding the topic. It appears that our OSP puddles have paramiko version packaged and we should use it for testing. 

e.g. link to rpm from the recent OSP17 puddle for http://rhos-qe-mirror-tlv.usersys.redhat.com/rcm-guest/puddles/OpenStack/17.0-RHEL-9/RHOS-17.0-RHEL-9-20220428.n.1/compose/OpenStack/x86_64/os/Packages/python3-paramiko-2.7.2-2.el9ost.noarch.rpm

It's a dependency for tempest and for other components (for example, some cinder and manila drivers use it to connect to appliances). According to Luigi with upgrading paramiko we can break py2 tests (on osp13).

Also he told me that it's important for CI jobs that hypervisor ssh key will be RSA one and not OPENSSH one. If not, please reprovision your hypervisor with the foreman (or infra-script).

FYI, Luigi sent this patch to add additional ssh keys in the post tasks
https://review.gerrithub.io/c/rhos-infra/cloud-config/+/537138
LGTM
This fixes most issues on OSP17.0 d/s CI jobs

With this new release we have problems logging to CirrOS images. The problem is common to all architectures (ubuntu, OSX, etc.). So we can try looking for another version of paramiko or updating the CirrOS image version. Please note the update of CirrOS image has also to happen separately for the downstream CI as the URL on such case is different one.
for ssh to cirros from rhel-9 we need to use ecdsa key, like tempest now does

Roman, I've been talking with Federico about this. Since tobiko installs paramiko on a venv using tox (under tobiko/.tox/py3/...), using a different paramiko version shouldn't affect other components running on the undercloud node, so tobiko can use its own paramiko version.
This is different for tempest because the tempest IR plugin installs the dependencies under ~/.local/....
Please Eduardo have a look at this workaround. Cheers

On further reflection I think we could remove the `create-instance-flavor-sort` option completely. We can derive the value from `create-instance-flavor-sort-key`. If we change `create-instance-flavor-sort-key` to have an empty default then

create-instance-flavor-sort = create-instance-flavor-sort-key is not None

The config.yaml entry would look like this:

  create-instance-flavor-sort-key:
    type: string
    default:

In terms of the option descriptions in config.yaml I think for each option you should say what it does and what the configuration options:

create-instance-flavor-sort-key: This option can be used to customise the order instances are sorted in. Supported values include id, name, ram, disk and vcpus (see https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/configuration/settings.html#create-instance-flavor-sort for more details)

create-instance-flavor-sort-reverse: This option can be used to set the instance sorting to either ascending or descending. Set True to sort in ascending order or False for descending order.

playbooks/generate_workspace.yml.message:
One of the issues I see with this is the fact that this means when a new user is trying to use Atmosphere, they will get self signed instead of LetsEncrypt out of the box.

Should we document this somewhere that "if you want LetsEncrypt, change this setting" -- or maybe we can take advantage of the fact that when Molecule runs, it uses `--tags`.

Alternatively, maybe we can find a way to manually provide the override when we call generate_workspace ?  I'm just trying to make sure our users know that there is a way to not end up with self-signed certificates.

But i think we can use tag for only converge and testof molecule. generate_workspace is called in create, you know.
I prefer to have var file for molecule instead of relying on this generate_workspace playbook for all variables. I thought this `generate_worksapce` playbook is to to set variables `intelligently`, like filling some missing credentials, fetching values from the output of other jobs or from the environment.

So such a variable as setting self-signed cert can be just configured using a var file, for example, we can keep molecue/default/group_vars/all/molecule.yml file with such variables specific for molecule CI.

(lines 87-90)

nodepool/driver/openstack/provider.py.message:
If feel like this doesn't quite capture what's going on with the "vcpus" probe here.

It seems that prior to the recent changes, we would get back a flavor object, but that could have "0" vcpu's listed, per [1]:

"ah, I guess I know now what is happening: vcpus is not set in the tested flavor and as such param is empty. Previously as part of normalization it was set to 0 in such case. This is a tricky one"

Now, we get back a flavor that doesn't have a vcpus field if the flavor doesn't set it.  This raises a few questions:

* The number of VCPU's doesn't seem like an optional component of the flavor?
* How are you supposed to get how many VCPUs a server instance has then?  Is there something else we should use here?
* If it's not there, should we assume "1"?  This doesn't seem documented in openstacksdk [2]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstacksdk/+/826543
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/openstacksdk/latest/user/resources/compute/v2/flavor.html#openstack.compute.v2.flavor.Flavor

Thanks for the details.  

So in short, the flavor can never not be filled in for an active server with the more recent sdks.  It's just the "id" field changed with sdk 1.0, confusing our check.

The comment in [1] is wrong IMO. Whether we check for "vcpus" or "ram" or "swap" or whatever doesn't matter, either all of them are there or none. The cases that can happen are:

a) Very old sdk or very old nova (not supporting microversion 2.47). In this case "server.flavor" will be a dict with only .id and .links and we need to consult our "flavors" list in order to get details about the flavor.

b) not-too-old sdk and nova: "server.flavor" is a dict containing .vcpus, .ram, etc. and we can simply use these values [3].

c) sdk 1.0: the result from b) will be returned as a Flavor object [2], which synthesizes an .id field from .original_name

The old code tries to distinguish a) and b) by checking for the presence of .id, which is missing in b). But it mishandles c), trying to use the flavors list with the id seens from the Flavor object, which fails and returns None because "flavors" is indexed by the flavor (UU)ID only and not by (original_)name. Also, servers may still be running that were created with a flavor that has since been deleted, so we couldn't find it in our "flavors" list even if we were checking by name instead of id.
So by checking for .vcpus we simply bundle b) and c) together, since in both cases we will have both vcpus and ram present in the flavor data.

[3] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=show-server-details-detail#show-server-details

At least with recent enough nova, i.e. >= pike, yes. I'm not really sure what sdk 1.0 will produce when running against even older clouds, but I also have no way of testing that and I'm not sure if anyone would still care.
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html#id43

What's really confusing is IMO not the pure existence of the id field, but that it has different content in the server.flavor context compared to the bare flavor context. In essence, these are two similar but not identical objects, so it is questionable for the sdk to use the same object type for both.

In the old case (where vcpu's would apparently be "0" in some cases?), construct_from_flavor() would still account for the RAM.  I am presuming at it could/was/is set, separate to vcpus?  

It seems now we're going to skip that too -- which seems wrong.

I'm not sure what to suggest without knowing answers to the above -- how do we really handle a missing "vcpu" field?

I'm sorry for not getting back to this.  After coming back to this, and re-reading the code again, it seems fine.  We'll likely get the info (new sdk) or if we don't (old sdk, unlikely anyway) we'll look it up and then, in the even more unlikley case, skip over it.  I think this is fine, thanks
I'm not sure what your intention is with this comment, do you want to change the code or only the comment? Feel free to submit a new PS with your idea, that might make discussing it easier.

Maybe I should make this a different patch then or drop it completely, but this is only going to happen in the case a) above and only in the case that the original flavor has been deleted. The old code would then simply fail, but my idea was that calculating a lower bound for the used quota, skipping servers that we don't have data for, would be still better than not having any quota information at all.

I think then this would be made clear if we did the continue in the branch where we are looking up the flavor, then?  something ~ like

 flavor = flavors.get(server.flavor.id)
 # ... only here with old sdk because all modern sdk's have returned
 # flavor info directly with the server info call ...
 # ... possible the flavor this server is running is has been deleted
 # and isn't in our cache, therefore skip if we don't find ...
 continue

?

I agree that execution of this code path is not particularly important.  More interested in making it very clear for future code explorers what the thinking was without having to go through this again! 😊

I'd actually push for a different approach to using this in the reconstructor, though it'd require knowing which replica the old primary was responsible for. Basically,

* if the ring is less than <configurable time period> old and
* we would try to reconstruct the recently-moved replica

skip it for now. Assume that the old primary will ship it over within <time period>, so don't go asking it *more* questions from a bunch of yahoos that need double the bandwidth to ship the frag. Instead, let the old primary focus on shipping parts off its disk as it sees fit.

Note that we may *also* want to use this to prioritize the reconstructor jobs for the old primary -- seems preferable to do the known-old-primary partitions ahead of the general handoffs.

How's the old code going to handle new rings? Seems like it'll blow up here with a TypeError.

At the same time, adding a separate replica_count_float key won't work great, either; we'll start reading the last_part_nodes table as part of the replica2part2dev table if it's a fractional-replica ring :-/ I guess we need to bump the version number, and maybe provide an option for writing old v1 rings? Or at least include an UpgradeImpact about how you need to continue writing rings with the oldest version of Swift in your cluster.

Yeah, I was thinking about upgrade impact and maybe even add the float replica count change as a patch first. This can get back ported. Then we add the extra last_primary array (this one) afterwards. So if anyone needs to rollback from the latter, they can still load their rings in old code and it just wont pull out the last_primary array.

OK, yeah -- new code with old rings should be fine, because even if we previously wrote down

 "replica_count": 3

when it was really more likw 2.5, the read() will come back short similar to the old code. 👍

So it's going to be a float instead of an int now, yeah? And that type difference will get preserved with the JSON round-tripping. Makes me wonder if I should update calc_replica_count() so it returns an int if it can do so with no loss of fidelity...

I don't know about including a handoff index. I kind of want to consider this an authoritative response when doing GETs/HEADs in the proxy.

For example, today on master, when we get back 404s from handoffs we ignore them when calculating quorum -- handoffs aren't expected to have data, so the 404 should be unsurprising. Combined with

 rebalance_missing_suppression_count = 1

we'll serve back a 404 on (Timeout, 404, 404) from primaries but a 503 on  (Timeout, Timeout, 404) -- assuming none of the 404s have timestamps associated with them.

With last_primary support, though, we aren't surprised if *one* of the four nodes have no data, but *two* 404s seem like a pretty good indication that we don't have anything for that name.  So rebalance_missing_suppression_count = 1 still seems to make sense. Deciding on the client response code seems more like considering 4 "primary" responses for 3 replicas -- and that 503 would either

* become a 200 if the last_primary had data,
* become a 404 if the last_primary responded 404, or
* stay a 503 if the last_primary also hit an error.

So maybe index=len(primary_nodes)+1 would work? It feels a little weird, but might be a reasonable option.

In this patch we also have get_last_part_node, which will be a None if it doesn't have one. So maybe pulling in this on a read in get_part_nodes rather then in get more nodes makes sense if we want something more authoriative.. Or should it get a handoff_index of -1 or a new dict value to indicate an authorative response.

get_part_nodes could include the primaries + dict(last_primary, last_primary=True). And change our best_response code around it... or in get_more_nodes with the same (for when we move into them) or a special handoff_index value if adding more metadata is too much. Something like:

 HANDOFF_AUTHORTIVE_INDEX = -1
But that could have handoff counting issues... just brainstorming 😊

Or a combination, index = len(primary_nodes)+1 AND last_primary=True 

But in either case it'll be about plumbing this into the proxy, so really just need to decide on an API for last_primaries.

maybe instead of "get_more_nodes(for_read=True)" we should update call-sites that are *interested* in the new behavior to call a different method...

"find_old_node_or_handoff"
"get_best_nodes_for_read"

maybe consider yielding a primary_index of... -1 or replica+1 instead of a "handoff_index"

i'm sure we have code that assumes everything coming out of get_more_nodes has a handoff_index 😞
